intro: Anguria gaudichaudiana, commonly known as the Hawaiian watermelon, is a climbing vine belonging to the Cucurbitaceae family. It is native to the Hawaiian Islands and is characterized by its large, lobed leaves and bright orange to red fruits. The plant thrives in tropical and subtropical climates, requiring full sun and well-drained soil. Its fruit is typically harvested when it reaches a deep orange color, indicating maturity. Anguria gaudichaudiana is valued for its edible, juicy fruits and is sometimes cultivated for ornamental purposes as well.
